  555. I'm replacing my original 4 star review, downgrading it to 1 star. Initially, it seemed to do a decent job but over the course of several months it just kept getting worse. It used to take 2 minutes for a great shave and now it takes 3+ for a barely average one. I like the design of the new head and it is easier to clean, however it is clearly inferior. I've now had it a year and I'm at the point of just sucking it up and purchasing a Braun because it appears that Norelco is not going to bring the original head design back. I never tossed the original RQ12/52 head that came with the razor even though it makes a terrible noise (I'm guessing because the plastic gears inside are worn). Just for fun, I put the old head back on and did a full shave the other day and it was fantastic. It's like the close shave that I have been missing out on for a year! It is my final belief that Norelco is cutting corners and their quality is suffering. If only I had known, I would have stocked up on the old heads before they discontinued them.
  556. I was somewhat reluctant to purchase this replacement head after reading so many negative reviews regarding the new design, but now that I've received it and used it, I'm overall satisfied with the purchase. I'll go into a bit of detail in an attempt to clear some misconceptions of this product:<br /><br />THE DESIGN: The replacement head is identical to the head found on the new 9000 series razors, including using the newer V-track cutting blades. The V-track blades look like little V-shaped scoops which Norelco claims are better at grabbing and guiding flat-lying hair. Like the 9000 series, once you buy the RQ12/62 head, you can subsequently replace just the blades using the somewhat cheaper SH90/52 replacement heads. (The heads are advertised as working in just the 9000 series but the instruction sheet that comes with this replacement head confirms the SH90/52 heads are compatible).<br /><br />Many reviewers have posted negative responses to the fact that the heads no longer flip up to allow for easy cleaning. Instead, the top of the head assembly pops off and the individual razor blades can be detached for cleaning by using an included orange plastic key. Initially I was put off by this change, but now that I've seen it in action after several uses it's grown on me. While the flip up heads seemed elegant, they were somewhat impractical for sink cleaning. In the old design, both the blades and the rotor shafts flipped up, creating deep wells that didn't always rinse clean with water from the sink. My old razor head easily got gunked up with stubble that didn't rinse away between manual cleanings. Getting to the blades required carefully opening a second metal hinge on the underside of the flip-up head which wasn't always easy to do.<br /><br />The new design, while less elegant in appearance, seems to actually be better for day to day cleaning. The rotor shafts remain attached to the main body of the razor and the area around the blades is shallower and seems to rinse the stubble away under the sink more effectively than the old design. Since I shave dry, I can also much more easily just tap out the loose stubble into the sink after each shave and I notice it comes out much more cleanly than in my old flip-up head.<br /><br />Overall I think the new design is a slight improvement. Yes it's less elegant (and feels less sturdy) than the previous design, but in practicality I think I'm able to much more effectively clean the razor and it's not a chore to pop the head off compared to flipping up the heads.<br /><br />SHAVE QUALITY: The new razor performs as well if not better than the original head of this razor. I can't give much comment as to whether the new V-track blades are any better than the UltraTrack blades in the original design, if only because my previous blades were so dull that my basis for comparison is stale. I use Williams Lectric Shave as a prep and it provided a smooth, comfortable and very close, especially on the neck.<br /><br />OVERALL: I'm satisfied with this product overall and am only taking a star off because both the razor head and the SH90/52 replacement heads are still significantly more expensive than the replacement blades for any previous Norelco model. Still, the new design is practical and effective once you get used to the changes and the shave quality was excellent. Hopefully Norelco standardizing on the SH90 blades across multiple products that will help drive down the price.
  557. The head worked as it should. It snaps on somewhat differently than the original and the other replacements I have purchased. The individual blades are somewhat harder to remove for cleaning but not to the point to lower the rating.

The travel case is effectively useless with this head. Also, as a matter of aesthetics, it looks out of scale and the coloring is not quite the same as the original.   622. Very satisfied with razor
  623. I have now used this replacement blade for 5 months. I find it to be FAR superior to the original. Change comes hard as we are all accustomed to habit. Cleaning the replacement however, is a snap. Easily pop off the three head attachment. Do NOT remove the entire head from the handle. Rinse the stubble from the housing then rinse the blades with hot water to inhibit bacteria. Extend the trimmer, then hang the entire unit upside down on the charging rack and let it dry for the next use. Nothing to it!
  624. The replacement head is better than the original head.

  626. I read many very negative comments before deciding to go the less expensive route and ordering this replacement head for my Norelco 1250X 8000 series electric razor. But, I thought, I'll try this replacement as there were slightly more positive comments than negative ones. Also, I could always bite the bullet and spring for the more expensive one if this one didn't work out. My razor is about 6 months old. However, my beard is very thick and it got to the point that it was taking me about 20-30 minutes to get a decent shave.<br /><br />I wanted to continue to use the Norelco and not revert to my safety razor because after a couple of neck surgeries, I had some rather bothersome scars. It had gotten to the point that I was turning myself into a rather messy &#34;self-sacrifice&#34; every time I shaved with my safety razor. Also, I had spent a bunch of money on this razor and I wanted to get more use out of it.<br /><br />Once my replacement head arrived, I immediately installed it on my razor. After splashing on some pre-shave lotion and letting it dry, I fired-up the Norelco. As I mentioned earlier, it had gotten to the point that I was taking 20-30 minutes to get a clean, smooth shave. With the new head, I was done in 10 minutes and it was a closer and smoother shave than I had ever received with the original Norelco head; even when the razor was brand new!<br /><br />Some complained that the replacement head didn't fit their razor. It fit mine perfectly. Some people complained that it was more noisy to use the replacement head. I can agree with that somewhat. But, I'm shaving, not trying to go to sleep. It's NOT that much more noisy. The ads for this replacement head claims a closer cut. I'm here to say, that claim is very valid. I've NEVER gotten as close a shave from any electric razor I've ever owned as the shave I got from my Norelco with this replacement head.<br /><br />Some complain about the individual floating heads not opening up, individually, for cleaning, as is the case with the OEM head. With this replacement head, the top comes off so all three floating heads are exposed for cleaning, at the same time. Other reviewers complain about the replacement head being made of plastic. I see their point, to a point. But, thus far, I don't see a reduction in quality. And, for ⅓ the cost of the original replacement head and a far, far closer shave, I would'nt care if the head were made of aluminum and wax paper; as long as it does what I want it to do.<br /><br />Norelco has been around for as long as I've been. I can still remember their TV commercials with Santa riding a sled of &#34;floating heads&#34; over the snow, in black and white, no less. One needs to realize that Norelco needs to produce a product that will compete with the rest of the market. And, if they can do that by using a different material(s), sell it for far less money and still have a high quality product, they will do it. Plus, if they allowed their quality to fall, they know they will lose their edge (no pun intended) and eventually all of their customers.<br /><br />Of course, this is just my opinion, based on my experience. I'm not trying to down-play those who have negative experiences with the replacement head. For those who had bad experiences, I would ask them to contact Norelco and discuss the issue with them. There may be a practical explanation as to why their experiences were negative.<br />_________________________<br />Update: 3/15/15<br />After using the RQ12+ for about 6 weeks, I can report that it's still performing satisfactorily. I shave about every other day and take the razor head apart once a week for cleaning. I break-down the head into its 10 component parts, wash each, individually, under warm tap water, allow them to dry, reassemble the components and reapply the razor head to the razor. There is a noticeable difference in the closeness of a shave, the longer one goes between cleaning. Once the blades are cleaned, it's like shaving with a new razor.<br /><br />Admittedly, I do miss the pop-up feature of the original blade assembly. But, upon figuring out the trick to disassembling, then reassembling the razor head, after cleaning, I'm not so sure that the design replacement head doesn't allow for a better job of cleaning the razor blades. The &#34;trick&#34; with disassembling, then reassembling the razor head lies with realizing that once the cover is removed, flip it over in your palm and be looking at it from its underside. From there, you can use your fingernails to rotate the orange retaining clips counter-clockwise, then lift them out of the way. Next, using your fingernail, pick out the razor blade from the blade cover. Next, using your finger, from underneath the cover (remember, you're looking at the assembly upside-down), push the blade cover out of its hole in the 3-blade assembly. Repeat this process for each of the 2 remaining blades. Now, clean each component. I use warm, running tap water, from my bathroom sink. Be sure to close the drain or place some sort of strainer over the drain so as to not lose any parts down the drain. Should there be any any residual left, I use an old toothbrush to remove it.<br /><br />Allow the parts to dry and reassemble the razor head by reversing the procedure. the parts are interchangeable! So don't worry about which component came off of which razor blade. NOTE: WHEN TAKING THE RAZOR HEAD ASSEMBLY APART, NOTE THAT THERE ARE NOTCHES ALONG THE EDGES OF EACH RAZOR HEAD COVER. ALSO, THERE ARE TABS ON THE ASSEMBLY COVER AND ON EACH RAZOR COVER. BE SURE TO ALIGN THE NOTCHES WITH THE TABS IN EACH CASE. OTHERWISE, YOU'LL NOT BE ABLE TO REALIGN THE COMPONENTS AND THEY WILL NOT FIT TOGETHER PROPERLY. Next, drop one of the circular blades into each razor cover. Be sure to place the cutting edges against the inside of the razor cover. Otherwise, the blades will be upside down when reattached to the razor and not cut anything. The final step is to reinstall the Orange retainer rings onto each razor. Again, align the notches on the retainer rings with the tabs on the razor covers. Rotate the retainer rings clockwise until they snap into place. Not much force is needed.<br /><br />It takes me about 15 minutes to disassemble, clean and reassemble my razor blades. It takes about 20 minutes for the parts to air-dry. So, roughly, 30 minutes total. Being as the razor is water-proof and can be used in the shower, waiting for the components to dry isn't really necessary. I just do it. Again, after a cleaning, my shave is just as good as any safety razor shave I've ever had.o miss the pop-up feature of the original blade assembly. But, upon figuring out the trick to disassembling, then reassembling the razor head, after cleaning, I'm not so sure that the design replacement head doesn't allow for a better job of cleaning the razor blades. The &#34;trick&#34; with disassembling, then reassembling the razor head lies with realizing that once the cover is removed, flip it over in your palm and be looking at it from its underside. From there, you can use your fingernails to rotate the orange retaining clips counter-clockwise, then lift them out of the way. Next, using your fingernail, pick out the razor blade from the blade cover. Next, using your finger, from underneath the cover (remember, you're looking at the assembly upside-down), push the blade cover out of its hole in the 3-blade assembly. Repeat this process for each of the 2 remaining blades. Now, clean each component. I use warm, running tap water, from my bathroom sink. Be sure to close the drain or place some sort of strainer over the drain so as to not lose any parts down the drain. Should there be any any residual left, I use an old toothbrush to remove it. Allow the parts to dry and reassemble the razor head by reversing the procedure. the parts are interchangeable! So don't worry about which component came off of which razor blade. NOTE: WHEN TAKING THE RAZOR HEAD ASSEMBLY APART, NOTE THAT THERE ARE NOTCHES ALONG THE EDGES OF EACH RAZOR HEAD COVER. ALSO, THERE ARE TABS ON THE ASSEMBLY COVER AND ON EACH RAZOR COVER. BE SURE TO ALIGN THE NOTCHES WITH THE TABS IN EACH CASE. OTHERWISE, YOU'LL NOT BE ABLE TO REALIGN THE COMPONENTS AND THEY WILL NOT FIT TOGETHER PROPERLY. Next, drop one of the circular blades into each razor cover. Be sure to place the cutting edges against the inside of the razor cover. Otherwise, the blades will be upside down when reattached to the razor and not cut anything. The final step is to reinstall the Orange retainer rings onto each razor. Again, align the notches on the retainer rings with the tabs on the razor covers. Rotate the retainer rings clockwise until they snap into place. Not much force is needed. It takes me about 15 minutes to disassemble, clean and reassemble my razor blades. It takes about 20 minutes for the parts to air-dry. So, roughly, 30 minutes total. Being as the razor is water-proof and can be used in the shower, waiting for the components to dry isn't really necessary. I just do it. Again, after a cleaning, my shave is just as good as any safety razor shave I've ever had.

The worst part is the shave itself! I put the old one back on while I wait for the &#34;old style&#34; replacement head and it shaves better!

  638. Just as I expected factory perfect new item

  640. this razor head shaved reasonably well, but it is poorly made. After two months I am having to buy new again.   642. I am the owner of a SensoTouch 3D 1250x shaver and needed replacement heads. All these negative reviews and cries of cheap plastic had me worried, but I reasoned I could always return it if I was unhappy, which seemed more sensible than buying a new shaver.<br /><br />The listed item has been changed from what previous reviewers received, as the replacement heads, which came in a box clearly marked as RQ12+, are not plastic at all, and are actually identical to the shaving heads for the new 9000 series shavers.<br /><br />So for the SensoTouch crowd, how are the new heads different from what we had before? There's slightly more rotation (&#34;eight directions&#34;) than with the RQ12 heads, though I can't say it matters as I had no problem reaching tough spots before. The new heads have slightly more space between them; in theory that means covering surface faster and finishing sooner, but in practice that leaves areas between blades uncut unless you keep making a circular motion on your face, so shaves aren't any faster. It's also basically impossible to shave under your nose without using a trimmer, which I had been doing anyway. While the 9000 series advertises a 30% closer shave, a week of daily use has shown no evidence of that for me; my facial hair is soft and not thick, so your results may vary. The shave itself is as smooth as before, with none of the pulling and tugging others reported from the lesser version they were getting. While I loved flipping the individual blade chambers open for cleaning the old heads, the new heads allow the top portion to be removed in one piece quite easily (but it always securely snaps in place for your next shave). As a dry shaver I actually find the new heads easier to rinse out, though I'm not a big fan of then leaving the outer portion separate from the shaver so both can air dry.<br /><br />If you own a SensoTouch 3D, I strongly recommend these replacement heads, and urge those who were unhappy with what they gotcirca September 2014 to try again.
  643. After having my old school head for over 2 years I figured it was time for a new set. To my amazement Norelco has changed the head completely and it is a whole new system. I reluctantly bought the new head and it installed easily. I gave this new head a chance for over two weeks. I have come to the conclusion that my old head (2 years plus old!) shaves my head and face closer and smoother than the new one, and much faster too.<br />TOTALLY disappointed in this 50+ dollar upgrade that's useless. Thanks a lot Norelco. Guess I am switching to the Dollar shave club.
  644. I love this shaving head. Been using them for about 4 months and I feel the shave is better than the original blades. I have tried several shavers: from rotary to foil. When using the RQ12, hair would leak out the assembly, making a mess around the sink. The RQ12+ heads have a slight pivoting in each head, which make easier to shave the hard to get areas around the neck and jawline. Both, dry and wet shave are great and leave no burning. I recommend them.

  665. When I saw that the old RQ12 shave heads were getting short in supply and the price started creeping up, I bought every RQ12 selling for a decent price that I could get my hands on. When I saw recently that Amazon was carrying these new RQ12+ (RQ12/62) heads for under $50, I decided to order on to test/compare to my RQ12 head that I recently loaded on to my razor.<br /><br />My impressions. First and most noticeable: the new RQ12+ units are LOUD!!! I use my razor to trim my ear hairs, and that RQ12+ is MUCH louder than the older RQ12s. The new RQ12+ head also feels/looks to be thicker and more bulks. I don't know for sure that the new RQ12+ heads are cheaply made, but the tolerances of the moving pieces for the new RQ12+ heads are certainly larger than the older RQ12 heads. I suspect because of this the blades in the new RQ12+ head will start pulling my whiskers out with wear on the unit.<br /><br />Cleaning the new head is definitely different, as others have pointed out. I can't say that it's any more difficult overall - perhaps a bit more work to do the daily rinsing, and a bit less work to do a deep clean. One thing that I noticed, however, is that the cost to purchase the foils and cutters (part no. SH90) is currently VIRTUALLY THE SAME PRICE as the whole new RQ12+ (RQ12/62) head that pops on top of your razor ($47.52 for the SH90 versus $47.92 for the RQ12/62 - though neither is currently in stock). This being Amazon, prices will no doubt jump up and down - however it makes no sense that the foils/cutters aren't much cheaper, in the $30 price range.<br /><br />I'm going to pop the new RQ12+ head back in its box and continue using the older RQ12 heads as long as they last...

Also, cleaning isn't as quick and easy as the original head that came with the unit.   688. I've been shaving with Norelco since 1971. Until now. I won't bore you by repeating what other one star ratings have said. I'm all about premium shavers with cleaning EASE like the RQ12 replacement head. The idea of disassembly with a special tool and dealing with separate blades is just nuts for a premium shaver. I have the Norelco 3D 1260 and would expect a hell of a lot better , especially considering the costs. My fix for the problem? The Braun 799cc. Great shave and the ultimate in cleaning ease. Goodby Norelco, it is sad that after so many years, you have decided to treat me like an ignorant moron who has no alternatives.

  699. There have been many negative reviews of these heads, mostly in comparison with the original replacement RQ12 heads. I find that cleaning these are actually much easier than the previous model once you master the easy task of pulling the assembly apart. Rinsing under running water is quick and effective, much quicker than having to hinge open each individual blade assembly as was the case previously. HOWEVER, these heads are noisy indicating to me that the tolerances are not good--parts are rubbing that shouldn't. Quality of the shave seems about the same, but I have had trouble over the past couple years with my neck whiskers and often run a multi-blade conventional razor over that area. This new head doesn't seem either better or worse than the previous one.

I'd say a shave with a fully charged Philips Norelco 1290X/46 Shaver 8800 using the RQ12+ at 8:00am yields a shave that feels like the original RQ12 about 7 hours after shaving. No kidding.   719. I was hesitating to buy the RG12+ because of the negative reviews on it, after a lot of thinking I decided to buy it for two reasons which are the the RQ 12's price is ridiculously high, and since Philipps stopped manufacturing the RQ12, that means it will be out of the market sooner or later.<br />I got the RQ12+ like 3 weeks ago, and I use it on a daily basis, I use it to chave my head, and my beard. I like this one better than the RQ12 !! Why???!!!. First the RQ12+ gives closer shave. The way I shave even with RQ12 by doing two rounds of shaving, I did two rounds of shaving with RQ12+ on my haed and the result was closer shave than the RQ12. ( My tow round of shaving is by shaving in two directions top to bottom and left to right and then on the second round by going on the oppposit directions bottom to top and right to left.). Second the RQ12+ is easy to clean, it comes with a tool that let you dissassmble the blades and clean them if you want to, but clean it with water without dissassembling works just fine, to get easier and better cleaning I recomend using shaving foam instead of shaving gel.

Overall a definite downgrade from the previous, which was excellent.<br /><br />So I have noticed that it pulls hair a lot more, to the point that it sometimes hurt (different shaving gel makes a huge difference with this head whereas the older one did not care).<br /><br />Also the blades have tiny gaps between them that the hair get stuck into. This causes two things: 1). every time the blade spins around the hair that is sticking out stabs you; 2). You need a tweezer to clean them out. This takes 10 minutes to do as there are many many blades... The head this replaces used to take 2 minutes to clean!
  745. My skin hurts when I use this, the shaving is not as smooth as the original one.
  746. Somewhat worse than the original. I really liked the original RQ12 head. The replacement is not quite as nice. Quality of the shave is about the same, definitely not a big improvement Philips claims. But the new head pulls hairs, making the shave less comfortable. The new head pivot range is reduced compared to the old one; this increases shaving time. I also like the feel and the sound of the old head better, feels more substantial and upscale. I really liked that the original head flips open and stays connected to the base. I can wash the head without getting my hands wet and stand the shaver to dry with the head open. The new one disconnects for cleaning. My hand gets wet when I wash the head, and I need to lay it down to dry separately from the handle. Looks like Philips switched to a cheaper and inferior design while keeping the price the same. The annoying part is that Philips pulls a bait and switch, as the original head is no longer made, and one has to settle for an inferior replacement. For this reason I will be reluctant to buy Philips products in the future. UPDATE 2/6/2015 After using RQ12+ for two months, I stand by my earlier assessment. The save quality is similar to RQ12. I am comparing shave quality to that of the original SensoTouch 3D head RQ12. Some people who report better shave quality compare it to the original Arcitec head, which makes sense to me, but I disagree with those who claim that RQ12+ gives a much better shave than RQ12 (when new and sharp). RQ12+ looses to the original RQ12 in several areas: * pulls longer hair * less convenient to clean and dry * smaller range of head motion * less pleasant to use: cheaper look, feel, and sound July 2015 update: reducing my rating to one star because of stability issues. The original head lasted over a year. The new one needs blade replacement after six months.

  755. Did not know entire head has to be removed for cleaning.
  756. The big label on the box says RQ12+, but on the bottom by the barcode it is identified as RQ 12/62, still made in the Netherlands. This is the same Shaving head used on the new top of the line Philips Norelco 9700 series. The main difference in the new series is a 3 speed setting base with enhanced digital setting displays. Kudos to Philips for offering the new \\"improved\\" head for older models like the SensoTouch 3D and the arcitec. Whether it is better that the old RQ 12/52, only time will tell. The Philips Norelco upgrade from the SpeedXL's to the Arcitec, was a disaster, with shave quality going down, according to most Consumer magazine reviews. I kept my SpeedXL with the HQ9 three row heads, until I saw the SensoTouch 3D getting good reviews. Here are my observations on the RQ12+. I thought the new head was noisy, until I firmly pressed the head onto the base, now the noise is about like the old head. The shave seems about the same, but like all Norelco's it will take about 2 weeks for the blades/cutters to properly seat in the combs. I'll update my opinion after the break-in period. The top portion with the three cutting heads can be easily removed or unsnapped from any of the three sides. You DON'T NEED TO REMOVE the individual blades to clean the head. Just tap it if dry shaving or rinse it if wet shaving. Just because you could easily remove the blades from the old 3D, didn't mean you should. Historically Norelco shavers have used plastic retaining rings to hold their cutting heads in place and it looks like they have returned to this concept. As in days of old, you will use the included orange tool to replace the three individual heads (SH90) rather than the entire head assembly. I like the new pivot assembly, where the 3 silver rings pivot rather that the old black plastic head sections. It feels & works the same in terms of shaving. Look at the Philips Norelco 9700 series on Amazon if you want a detailed look at the new head. Finally a comment about dry shaving, from a guy that has been doing it for a long time, from Remington Rand slot heads to Braun foils to these wonderful rotaries. Dry shaving is very convenient if done right. Wash your face with soap & water to remove skin oils & plump the hairs with moisture. Wait 5 to 10 minutes for your skin to really dry out before shaving. I use the period to make my morning coffee etc. I know wet shaving is nice, but if I'm going to use foam or a gel, I'd just as soon use a razor blade. Hope this info is helpful for all of you considering this replacement head. UPDATE: After 3 weeks use, these blades have broken in nicely. Shave is even better!

I am satisfied with the RQ11, but hope that Philips Norelco does not foul this up with a cheaper replacement head like the RQ12+ has turned out to be. Save your money and don't buy this blade replacement.

  773. I was skeptical given some reviews. I too was hoping to purchase the previous version of this replacement head. But, having used this product for more than 3 months I can say that my fears were unfounded.<br /><br />The performance of the blades is as excellent as what they replaced. It's true that the spindles are made of plastic now, as opposed to metal, as are the blade housings, but the plastic is good quality and strong. I daily remove the blade cover plate to clean the head and I have not noticed any issues nor has there been any issues.<br /><br />If you were pleased with your shaver using the factory heads, you'll find the same results with this replacement.   774. Like the shave, haven't had to clean it yet.
  775. I first reviewed this item over a year ago when I purchased a replacement head. I just purchased another set at the manufacturer's suggested replacement date. Again, I was doubtful about paying the &#34;high&#34; price for these replacement heads. I read all the reviews and wondered if something had changed. But I like my Arcitec and decided to try it again. Good decision. In my earlier review (a year ago), I complained about the missing cleaning tool. This package included the plastic tool used to disassemble the head for thorough cleaning.. I have been using the shaving head for about a month now and the shave is even better that I recall from a year ago. Perhaps the manufacturer's estimated life of one year is overly optimistic. Read the directions carefully and clean as directed. I run the shaver head under warm water (with the shaver running) and then remove the head and rinse both parts of the assembly. About once a week, I take the head fully apart and rinse. I have tried using the shaver both before and after showering. If you have time, I think the shaver works best an hour after showering.

  780. The description of this item does not full indicate it is a total redesign of the original 12/52 shaver head.   784. I've been using a Norelco 1250X ever since I discovered how wonderfully it shaved. I have two, one at home and one in my travel kit.   792. Seems to work well, easier to clean blades.
  793. This replacement to the RQ12 pulls at your whiskers, unlike the original RQ12 flip out set.
  794. Note this is the new design. It does not work as well as the original design, and is not easy to clean. Very disappointing.
  795. A big step backwards for the 1290, a baby step forward for the Arcitec. I searched for a replacement when the replacement light lit on my Senso Touch 3D 1290. I soon discovered that the replacement, this RQ12+; was one of the lowest rated products from this brand. The original replacement head, the RQ12 was on offer for 169.95 roughly the cost of the full razor. More searching and I found an Amazon vendor offering the RQ12 for 69.99 I ordered, my order of an RQ12 was confirmed. When I opened the box it contained the RQ12+. I contacted Amazon and they contacted the vendor and arranged a refund of the price difference between what I paid and the Amazon price of the RQ12+.<br /><br />I used the RQ12+ with the 1290 and it was less comfortable and effective than the year old original head. I then mounted it to an Arcitec that I had retired in favor of the 1290. The RQ12+ would not go in straight but rotated about 10 degrees. It outperformed the stock Arcitec. I shaved with the Arcitec, and followed up with the year old 1290. The year old 1290 removed hair the new RQ12+ had left behind.The problem is that the Arcitec equipped with the new head won't fit in the charging pod, so you must remove the head to charge.<br /><br />Using the RQ12+ on the 1290 is like putting no name tires on your Porsche. I have been shaving with Norelco since 1974. Bring back the proper head before your customers go elsewhere, alstublieft.
  796. Just like many of the others here who post poor ratings with this &#34;replacement&#34; for the original RQ12, my impressions of the RQ12+ is that it's a very cheaply made replacement. The original head had swing up features for each of the three blade/comb assemblies, allowing one to easily flip them up, hold it under the faucet to clean them out, then flip them back down into place (at which point I always put it in the automatic cleaner often sold with my unit). The RQ12+ pulls all three heads (blade/comb combined) off in one sub-assembly from the main head assembly, much less convenient. You can't use the shaver handle to hold onto to clean everything, you have to hold the three-blade/comb assembly with your fingers under the faucet (and since I use the hottest water my faucet can put out, that's uncomfortable).<br /><br />My RQ12+ head assembly broke the fourth day I used it. I replaced it 1/2/15 (my annual &#34;change the shaver head&#34; date), and on 1/5/15 noticed a grinding noise coming from the head. I pulled off the top part (spilling hair stubble everywhere) to see what the problem was, and one of the three head/comb assemblies fell out of place. The little orange plastic retention piece had &#34;clicked&#34; out of it's retention position. I put it back together, started again, and the same thing happened. After the third cycle of stop - reaffix - start again I could tell it was simply a screwy piece of cheap plastic trash, and was permanently defective. Sigh. I put back on the previous RQ12 head that I had replaced and life was good again.<br /><br />Also, as others have noted, the quality of the shave from the RQ12+ is inferior to the RQ12. Even the year-old RQ12 I put back onto my unit after the RQ12+ broke (again, after four days of use), was vastly superior to the RQ12+ at its first use.<br /><br />I've been a Norelo user for about 40 years now. Very disappointed that, first Norelco doesn't have the original RQ12 heads available, except for the ridiculous price of ~$185 (almost what I paid for the complete shaving system), and second that they would even consider suggesting that the RQ12+ is an acceptable product, much less a replacement for the RQ12. It's insulting to any customer who bought into one of the higher end shavers that use the RQ12.<br /><br />Come on, Norelco, you've always been better than this! Get your act together.
  797. I have been using the replacement head for over a month now. I am not a huge fan of the design change, I liked the flip up heads previously for cleaning but the new ones will do.   838. No, you do not need to buy a new razor. The RQ12+ is not the disaster the one-star reviews imply. It is far from perfect–see below–and may not be due five starts, which I gave to offset some of the one-star reviews that are over the top. I have only shaved twice with the RQ12+ on my series 8000 and the quality of the shave is the same. The place under my nose is still hard to reach to get all my mustache. The stubble on my neck that is hard to clean shave is still hard to clean shave. And the parts of my beard that are easy to shave are still easy to shave. Given that it is supposed to take three or four weeks to break it in, it may turn out to shave better.<br /><br />The Norelco shaver is a very inconvenient shaver to use in the first place and the RQ12+ has made that worse. Instead of opening up the blades, rinsing them, and then leaving them open to dry, the RQ12+ must be removed from the razor to be cleaned. You are supposed to use hot water, but unlike the original blades, you must get your hands wet to rinse the blades, so–and this is a warning they put in the packaging–you must make sure the water is not too hot. Once you have rinsed the blades you are told to air dry them, but your choices are to put them back on the razor (shielding one side from air flow) or lay them on a surface (shielding one side from air flow and requiring someplace to put them where they will not get knocked around and damaged). Once a month you are told to disassemble the blades one at a time (to avoid getting them mixed up which requires re-breaking them in) and clean each one. To do that they give you a little orange plastic tool. Assuming you do not lose the tool, you have to use it to disassemble one blade, clean it, let it dry, and re-assemble it. Then repeat that whole process two more times. Although there is no mention of it in the instructions (and I use that word loosely), if you have the little cleaning system, you can use it. I assume it does as good a job as the once-a-month cleaning.<br /><br />If you are thinking about getting a new razor anyway, I recommend you go with a Braun. I used Braun for years and tried the Norelco to see if I like to shave wet. I have found that having wet shave available is not something I need. The Norelco is much less convenient to travel with. The Braun fits in a case about the size of a hard-shell glasses case. The shave quality is close enough, the differences are subjective. The Norelco is quieter, although the RQ12+ makes it noisier and has a metal on metal sound. My wife says I shave faster with the Norelco, but I haven't noticed.
  839. Squeals like a stuck pig. I waited too long to get my money back. I have used Norelco razors for decades, and this is the last straw. What a waste of 55 dollars. F..k off Norelco. And Philips too!

At the time of this writing, DR is selling these blades for $189, which is more than I paid for my 1250x itself! Save yourself some future money and pick up a Braun Series 7. The top-of-the line model (790) is only $5 more than this... for the entire razor/cleaning system! Not to mention it has better reviews than any Norelco razor out there. The blades last twice as long (18 mos vs 9), and are half the price of the cheap Norelco 12+ blades, which they're trying to pass off as replacements for the much better blades the razor came with.<br /><br />I've been a Norelco customer for many, many years. Shame on both DR and Norelco!
  856. The RQ12+/62 replacement head reviewed here is the exact same head that's on Norelco's new top-of-the-line 9000-series shavers. There are many 1-star reviews of this replacement head from customers that have 8000-series shavers yet the average review score for the 9000-series shavers on Amazon is 4.5 stars. That doesn't add up. The head assembly, combs, and blades are exactly the same on the 9000-series and the RQ12+/62 replacement heads. And as far as a shaving experience, those parts ARE the shaver. The 8000-series shavers originally used the RQ12 head. This is the head that now goes for ridiculous prices by scalpers - $130 and up - since it apparently it is no longer being produced by Norelco as a replacement part. So what's the difference between the original RQ12 and the new RQ12+ reviewed here? Each head on the RQ12 is mounted on one of three vertical pivots that make up the base of the head assembly. This allows each head to move independently up and down. The RQ12+/62 has all three heads on a single base with no vertical pivots; as you're shaving, if one head moves down the others have to move up like a lever. The RQ12+/62 heads do, however, pivot laterally as they move across your face. The RQ12 heads don't. Each head on the RQ12 is mounted on a hinge. The heads individually pop up for cleaning. On the RQ12+/62 you remove all three heads at once as a single assembly. To entirely remove the blades for thorough cleaning on the RQ12 you snap open a small retainer, also mounted on a hinge. On the RQ12+/62 to remove the blades you unsnap them with a provided plastic tool. (Note that the RQ12+/62 actually takes less effort to get really clean than the RQ12 since it's much easier to directly access the heads and blades.) Each RQ12 cutting head has three rows of blades. The outermost row has the Lift and Cut mechanism. The innermost row has round holes on the surface of the comb to cut stubble more efficiently. The RQ12+/62 has two rows of blades. The outermost row has Lift and Cut, V-shaped slots in the comb, and V-shaped blades that Norelco says give a 30% closer shave (the RQ12's blades are straight). I'm using a new RQ12 head that came with my 8100 (1250X) shaver and a new RQ12+/62 replacement head that I bought to see what the fuss was all about (I was going to have to buy one eventually anyway). What I've found is that the original RQ12 looks more substantial. It's more high-end and complex in appearance and then there's those fancy hinges on the cutting heads. It also feels somewhat more comfortable on your face than the RQ12+/62. The replacement RQ12+/62 has a more pedestrian appearance and looks less sophisticated. Perhaps that might help explain why there's such a discrepancy between the 9000-series shaver reviews and the reviews for the RQ12+/62. Here people are comparing the new head to something they're used to. On the 9000-series page they're just using the shaver (again, with the exact same heads) and telling you about the results of shaving with it. And while it may feel slightly less comfortable than the RQ12 the RQ12+/62 gives you a closer shave. I shave every day and have somewhat thick hairs and the RQ12+/62 feels more like I shaved with a standard razor than if I use the RQ12. Between the two I'd rather use the RQ12+ replacement head. Overall, for me anyway, getting a closer shave without having to use a standard razor outweighs everything else. And sorry, but some of these extremely negative comments just don't match up with what I've experienced.
  857. It seems that Norelco has stopped making the original RQ12 replacement head and only makes the RQ12+. They claim it is a drop in replacement consisting of the new style blades and adapter. The blades only need to be replaced with the &#34;upgrade&#34; and not the entire head assembly. Here's the kicker - while the head does fit, it is no longer of the correct size to fit some of the accessories which came with the shaver. Further, they instruct the user to remove the entire head assembly when using the charging pod for the Arcitec model. I bought the shaver originally because it came with the jet clean stand. Now the head is a slightly different shape and barely fits the stand, let alone being able to immerse in the cleaning solution deeply enough for a good cleaning. As other reviews state, the overall design has cheap plastic retaining rings to hold the blades in place and needs a special provided tool to disassemble. I found that fingers work just as well. The original RQ12 design had metal retaining springs and was much more durable. On a positive note - overall shave is comparable after the skin adjusts to the new blades and head. I really wish Norelco would not take a perfectly good design and mess with it..... Update on 3/16: the heads got very noisy and the seal came off of the head assembly. Shaved terrible halfway into the life of the blades. I am forced to buy a new shaver because it is no longer worth the cost of the cheaply made replacement parts.
  858. This replacement head is far superior to the original. The shave is wonderful and much faster.
  859. works just fine, quick shipping too.
  860. Unlike some other people writing reviews, I have had no problems with this replacement head. I have a Norelco Arcitec razor that originally used the RQ10 head but it seems like they no longer are being sold, so I had to switch to this RQ12 replacement. I have been using it for a month now, and I find that it gives me an even closer shave than the RQ10. It also shaves my neck much faster than the RQ10 as I had to repeatedly go over and over to get a close shave. When I'm finished every day, I pop the assembly off, brush out the loose hairs, and stick it on my charging/cleaning dock. They only bad thing about this head is that it does not fit into the travel charger.
  861. These blades work great. Perfect fit for my electric razor.
  862. As others have stated, this newer &#34;plus&#34; design is inferior to the old one. The heads don't pivot as freely and are tough to clean if you use any sort of shaving cream or gel. I also find my face gets cut much more often -- yes, my face gets cut up from this.<br /><br />Really hoping they bring back the old design.
  863. After reading the reviews I was not sure what I was getting to replace the head of my Phillips Norelco 3D electric shaver. The package arrived and I reviewed the contents of the package. I found the new RQ12+ shaving head complete, a new cover & a blade removal tool. Surprised to receive a new cover with the shaving head since my old one has been replaced twice already. To install the new shaving head was simple. Hold the shaver and pull the old head straight up away from the shaver. Poped right out. Open the new shaving head & simply line up the connector and push it back on the shaver. That's the entire process. The RQ12+ is a different shaving head then the original. It opens by removing the entire blade section to clean and snap it back in like the older models. I personaly never liked the new design of pulling up the blades to wash them. The real test was the shave. It was closer & faster, like new again. This Phillips Norelco 3D electric shaver is the best they make, but the blades do wear out. Installing the new RQ12+ was simple & easy, bottom line I was happy with the replacement head using the new RQ12+ Fast clean shave like new.
  864. I am a long term Phillips customer and this 3-D model is superb when used with an electric shaver pre-shave liquid. I use the CVS brand and it works fine. The replacement heads fit perfectly.
  865. Ordered it hoping it would fit an older model. It did, and it cuts better than the original
  866. I originally bought my Philips Norelco shaver at Costco, and was getting ready to order a new replacement head. I had saved the replacement head link to my wish list, but when I clicked on the link I went into shock!!!! Originally it was priced at around 50 bucks or so, but to my surprise it was now close to 200 bucks. Then I saw the link to a newer replacement and was relived that it was only $47, that was until I started reading all the dismal reviews for the newer replacement head. After doing a little research I decided to return my shaver to Costco, got to love their return polices, and purchased a Panasonic ES-LF51-A Arc4, which is without a doubt the closest and most comfortable shave I've ever had.<br /><br />Way to go Philips, you just lost another happy customer, thanks to your poor decision making process, which lead you to believe that offering an inferior replacement head, which probably saved you a few cents, was somehow a good idea.
  867. I have one shaver head that keeps coming off and I haven't been able to fix it.
  868. Sept. 2015 UPDATE: I replaced this shaver with a new model from Panasonic. The Panasonic cost 2/3 as much, yet shaves much better, feels better, even sounds better. &#60;/UPDATE&#62; Immediately after using this, without having read any reviews, I said to my wife, &#34;If this had been the original head, I would've returned the shaver immediately. I would never buy a shaver if this head was the only option.&#34; The original SensoTouch 3D head allowed you to relax and not even think about shaving, while providing a cutting-edge shave. Now that's luxury. This new head makes shaving a chore again. The shave was definitely not as close as the original head's. The space between heads is too great, and it caught on my chin and upper lip. I've never had that happen before (been shaving for 24 years). Other 'cons' include the cheap plastic construction (I won't be surprised if it breaks), and having to remove the top of the head assembly in order to clean it. Apparently, the hinged heads of the original design were too expensive to manufacture. Not a big deal, really, but higher price points demand more differentiating factors. Every shaver at any price cuts facial hair, so details matter. Even the sound that this new head makes is annoying, compared to the lower whirring chorus of the old one. With this new head, the SensoTouch 3D shaver has become more about form than function. I hope that Norelco will read these reviews and take them into consideration. I replace my shavers only when the motors are just about dead, but I may make an exception if the head design doesn't improve.
  869. Terrible redesign. The old version was a great, smooth shave and easy to flip open to clean each time. This new design doesn't cut nearly as close and requires taking it fully apart to clean. I've used electric shavers for 30 years. I've tried other brands in the past but Norelco was the only one that gave a smooth shave. Well, it no longer does. You'd think technology would allow these to get BETTER, but instead they are going in the wrong direction, while &#34;real&#34; razor blades I see are constantly innovating. As a result, after those 30 years I've now switched to a regular razor blade. What a difference THAT makes!
  870. Falls apart. However, it's the only thing that doesn't cut me when shaving, so I guess I'm stuck with this. Previous model was higher quality.
  871. As stated. Best shave ever.
  872. This is not like the original. Difficult to open and some parts can fall apart when you clean them out.The old blades just popped up.This looks like Norelco made this change.
  873. Totally disappointed in Norelco for discontinuing (or whatever) the RQ12. This doesn't shave like the RQ12 or feel like it on my face. With all the ridges on the metal bezel surrounding the blades, it doesn't take a genius to know why it's not as smooth running across your face. If Norelco doesn't bring back the RQ12 I'll never buy another one of their shavers. Considering all the similar negative reviews here as I've written, if Norelco doesn't respond in some manner it says a lot about the company's lack of consideration for it's customers.
  874. Terrible product. Quality is poor and it's a PAIN to use. It feels like instead of cutting the hair it pulls it 1 by 1 making shaving really painful. Great dissapointment because the shaving head that came with my sensotouch 3D was painless to use. If I could give it 0 stars I would.
  875. This replacement head is definitely NOT an improvement over the RQ12. The RQ12+ is terrible compared to the RQ12. Using the RQ12 head/blades was a pleasure, providing a wonderfully-close shave. If I didn't shave for several days in a row, the RQ12 barely pulled, with no pain.<br /><br />Not so for the RQ12+. It does not provide a close shave, and requires multiple passes to provide an acceptable shave. If I go a few days without shaving, the RQ12+ is downright painful to use. I hate this thing. The only positive thing I can say about it is that it IS easier to clean than the RQ12.<br /><br />Thankfully I kept my old RQ12 and will go back to it and throw this in the garbage. Once my old RQ12 stops working decently, then I'll purchase a different brand of electric shaver. Thanks for nothing Phillips. I suppose I should pursue some sort of satisfaction guarantee to see if I can get my money back for this crappy RQ12+.
  876. Although the item is what I ordered and it works as expected, there is no need for a customer to have to order the complete assembly. The picture shown on this page does not show all of the components that came with my order. It also included a plastic cover for the item shown. As a customer all I really need is the replacement blades, not the whole assembly that the blades come in. The cost for these unnecessary components makes the replacement cost as much as buying one of Norelco's cheaper shavers that comes with an additional set of replacement blades. Yes, I know this is the top of the line titanium blades, but even with the foil cover, it could (and should) cost a lot less.

  884. After reading so many negative reviews about the RQ12+ replacement shaver head, and a handful of positive reviews, I didn't want to believe that Norelco had ruined my great SensorTouch 3D 1250x shaver, wiped out the $220 investment I made 3 years ago and forced me into the arms of a competitor.<br /><br />But they did.<br /><br />I should mention that I always shave in the shower and use shaving foam. My beard is relatively light and grows every which-way, so regardless of the shaver it takes several passes to get a close shave. About 10 years ago or so I tried several different electric shaver models, including one Norelco, and they all failed in the shower due to water leakage. And they didn't shave very close. I spent the next decade shelling out big bucks for the various Gillette Fusion upgrades, including the powered models, and ever-more expensive blades. Got a close shave but got nicked a lot, too.<br /><br />Finally, I found the Norelco SensorTouch 3D 1250x. What a great razor! It worked flawlessly in the shower -- water simply can't get inside the mechanism. The shave was nearly as close as the Fusion blades. And the cleaning system was excellent. I felt that I'd finally found the answer.<br /><br />I don't shave every day, so the first head lasted 18 months. I replaced it with another RQ12/52 and the shave continued to be excellent. 18 months later, I couldn't buy the RQ12/52 anymore, except at outrageous prices -- some greater than what I paid for the 1250x shaver and cleaning system. I read the RQ12+ reviews with some trepidation, but there were enough positive reviews to give the new head a shot<br /><br />The first time I used the RQ12+, I thought it was better than the negative reviews indicated. But the more I shaved with the RQ12+ them more I noticed that the shaver was missing a lot of area on each pass and it was taking more and more passes to get a close shave. Some specifics: The RQ12+ head couldn't deal with the heaviest part of my beard, theupper lip and chin. The shave was never close and I couldn't get all the way to the nostrils. Didn't have either problem with the RQ12/52. Also, I frequently got an ingrown hair near the corner of my upper lip. It was in nearly the same spot every time. Had to pull it out with tweezers. I guess the hair wants to flop over and grow down, and the RQ12+ head couldn't lift it up.<br /><br />I decided to put up with this for at least a month to make sure it wasn't just a case of my beard and shaving style needing to adjust to the new heads. In fact, I did better than that -- I used the RQ12+ for three months. But the shave never improved and I finally gave up. It was hard to flush $220 down the drain, but I'd had enough. I did a bunch of research and bought the Braun Series 7 799CC-6WD CC4 Wet & Dry Shaver:<br /><br />http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00BWRLJ6O?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00<br /><br />I couldn't be more pleased with the Braun 799CC. The shave is actually closer than the Norelco 1250x with the RQ12/52 head. Smooth as a straight razor, but without the nicks. I can go more days without shaving than I could before. What really surprises me is how even the shave is. My beard never grew back so evenly with the Norelco. The Braun 799CC works great in the shower and the cleaning/charging system is better than the Norelco.<br /><br />So, even though I'm disappointed and angry at having my investment wiped out, I'm glad to have found a better shaver.<br /><br />Very bad call, Norelco.
  885. Contrary to some reviews, I find these replacement heads cut quicker and closer than the original ones. Popping the blades off on this for rinsing is simpler than flipping open the 3 heads separately on the original blades, and ends up being easier to clean out. I would purchase these again.

  890. Works perfectly. Yes this head is different to the original one and yes some of the internal mechanism now features plastic parts but no this is not an inferior head. I can't really say I can tell the difference between the original head brand-new and this new head brand-new - both resulted in a super close shave out of the box.
  891. better than the original.
  892. I bought these to replace the RQ12 heads on my 1250x. They have as much or more range of motion than the RQ12 had with larger blades. The cleaning process is different - instead of peeling back each blade, you pull the entire blade assembly off of the head. It's just as easy (actually saves time) and gives greater access to the blades and the head for more thorough cleaning. These also come with a tool to remove the individual blades if you need to do so.
  893. New style, easier to clean
  894. I Bought the most expensive razor Norelco makes and have had nothing but grief. Like an idiot, I have replaced the head three different times at insanely high prices. Although the shave was good, not one of the heads lasted longer than 2 months before it &#34;ate&#34; the blades. So, finally wising up, it sits in the drawer, waiting for Norelco to get their head out and make it something usable. I've used Norelco for 20+ years. No more.
  895. The reviews I read concerning the replacement head for my Norelco Senso Touch 3D almost stopped me from purchasing the RQ12+. The RQ12+ head is different than the older one but performs as though the shaver was brand new. No issues and very satisfied in the first 6 months of use ! ! ! ! RQ12+ is easy to install and easy to clean. Cleaning the head is a two handed operation where you may use your thumb nail to depress the tab between the any of the round shaving heads and with the other hand use a nail to pry open the head at the outer portion of the nearest round shaving head. Tap both parts of the shaving head on the side of the sink, then snap it back together and you are all set. If you determine that a more thorough cleaning is needed you can use the tool included to remove the blades from the head and rinse under running water. What I also discovered was that you have the option when the blades have dulled to replace just the head and blades. See SH90/52 for replacement blades for the RQ12+ head.
  896. Awful shaving head, the parts get loose while you're shaving. The original head for the shaver had an easy cleaning process with parts not getting loose. Every time you have to clean the new replacement head the parts come loose - blades, plastic holder and a pathetic plastic wheel to fix them again - and you waste valuable time assembling them again. Awful
  897. Cheap workmanship-----.
  898. Great price, did not have to chase all around tow.
  899. So far so good. I am a bit worried about cleaning the blades since they don't pop open but it is nice getting a clean close shave again.
  900. Negative reviews might come from surprise: This RQ12+ is not like the discontinued RQ12/52 that it replaces. (This set of 3 heads is pulled off for cleaning, rather than each head flipping up on the RQ12/52.) This isn't quite as easy but avoids the mess of water draining out of the shaver. More importantly, the RQ12/52 was not truly 3D. The RQ12+ heads now tilt sidewise in their holders which still tilt radially, as in the old RQ12/52. So there is an additional floating direction. Finally, the individual shaving heads (cutters and combs) can now be replaced (Philips Norelco SH90), rather than replacing the entire RQ12+. That saves a few bucks. More importantly, if a single shaving head is damaged, it can be switched out. ...At first trial, the RQ12+ shave seems as good as the discontinued RQ12/52.

  918. I have the Norelco 3D Senso Touch, and couldn't find a replacement head online or even in the stores. Then this new version of the RQ12 that came in, which provided another option. It feels somewhat different on how the heads curve, but the design has changed on how far apart the heads are now. It cuts the same as I remember when I first got this electric razor close to 2 years now. And much easier to cut the hair than now. Now that I replaced the head that was already on it from back then.<br /><br />It took me awhile after I shaved to get the 3 individual shaver heads back on the replacement head. Taking them out was easy enough. I found that I needed the individual heads lined up with the replacement head's holes. If it's crooked, the plastic orange holders will not work correctly to hold the heads back in. It's kind of weird having to line them up each time, and they can shift easily out of alignment. But after the first time, I'm already used to it. I could see why almost everyone on here complained about it though.<br /><br />The individual heads don't collect nearly as much hair as the older head. I just snap off the top of the replacement head, and the hairs collected on the bottom portion are mainly there already. So I probably don't have to clean out each individual head as often now. This does take getting used to, still it works in shaving fine for me.

  929. I have a tough beard and I'm on an even tougher budget. So after reading the many negative reviews on Amazon and elsewhere I didn't want to buy the RQ12+ for my Arcitec razor if I could at all avoid it. Consequently, I went to Bed Bath and Beyond because their website left off the + sign from the product description (and I had a coupon). Of course the + was on the box when I arrived to pick one up at my local store.<br /><br />I just had my first shave and my face is stubble free, which is why I am giving this product five stars. That's not to say that the criticism is not valid. The replacement head has some major differences from the original. Frankly, Norelco could have done a better job explaining them in the instructions.<br /><br />I am attaching a side-by-side photo of the old head (left) and the new head (right). As you will see in the photo, I placed the included orange tool on top of one of the blade covers so you can get a better sense of how to use the tool. This was not obvious, at least not to me.<br /><br />Each of the three blades on the left lift up but stay attached to the razor head. The RQ12+ on the other hand (right) requires you to place a fingernail in a groove to detach all three bladdes as a single unit. From this position you can rinse them or you can use the orange tool (shown in the picture) to remove each protective cover and access each blade separately. It was more confusing than anything else, but it didn't take long to figure out despite the lack of clear instructions.<br /><br />In installing the new head for the first time, I held the power button down for a few seconds until my razor reset as the instructions say to do. This was no big deal either and I have no idea why I had to do this.The instructions also say to remove the entire head from my razor in the case of a Norelco Arcitec when charging the unit in the plastic storage case or pod in Norelco lingo. I haven't done that yet but it sounds easy enough.<br /><br />I will revisit this review as more time goes by. But I would not hesitate to recommend this product thus far.t I would not hesitate to recommend this product thus far.
  930. Do NOT even think of buying the Norelco Arcitec. In fact, from what I now know, I would strongly recommend not buying any Norelco products. First of all, it is noteworthy to understand that Norelco has discontinued ALL service operations in the US and Canada. Can you imagine that your shaver's battery will need replacement in the next couple of years? Sorry, Norelco has NO OPTIONS for that replacement. I guess that works for them since they hope you will then buy a new shaver. You will also notice on the Norelco Architec shaver that the cord can NOT be inserted into the shaver, but only into the charger. When the battery can no longer be charged, it can not be powered by the cord either. Next, you will want to consider the RQ12+ Replacement Head. While the original Architec head shaves smoothly, fast and close, the new RQ12+ is poorly manufactured and has the following problems. 1. It has bigger holes and causes the shaver to actually jam on a thick 2 day beard growth. 2. The movable heads now have edges that protrude against the contours of your face and they will catch on your chin and elsewhere. 3. Shaves with this RQ12+ take longer. 4. Shaves with the RQ12+ are not nearly as close. Thankfully, I kept the old original head, and after suffering through the RQ12+ for a 45 days, replaced it with the original head that had 1 year of wear. Immediately, I noticed that the original head was smoother, closer and faster. There really was NO comparison! It is now clear to me that making cheaper products and offering no service is Norelco's new business model. I have spoken with their customer service reps twice and they simply take notes an apologize. They can offer NO remedies to my concerns, and only indicate the 'company line' that the new RQ12+ is &#34;better&#34;. This is absolute baloney and, obviously, clear indications of just one more corporation that has been taken over by Greed and Deception. You have been warned!

When that second razor head got dull I ordered this one online, and it cuts as poorly as the 1+ year old razor head I had been using. I do NOT recommend this product and will not be buying another.

  948. Outstanding product. Much improved...cleans more easily by far, self sharpening is working.

  956. I'm with most other reviewers: this thing sucks. Since Philips has decided to go this route, I'm shopping for a new razor. Gaaaa! Just when I thought I had a keeper!!! Very unhappy, and will keep this razor in hopes that Philips will go back to the previous replacement (without it costing $200!!).
  957. I was really worried due to all the negative remarks, but after using the new head, it's actually better. The biggest problem with the previous 3-hinges head was emptying the shavings was awkward. It took 2-3 rounds of opening and closing each of the heads to tap out all the shavings, and a few times the clasps came undone, spilling the blades into the sink.<br /><br />The new design is just two pieces - the blades and the body. Takes two hands, but emptying is now fast. Since it's a daily task, it's a huge benefit.
  958. The heads are bigger and are spaced farther away from each other, not allowing for a smooth shave on your chin. I miss my old blades.
  959. Quick and easy to replace. Heads work fine.
  960. As others have already stated hundreds of times, this replacement head is absolutely terrible. It rips at the beard and doesn't even get close to the original heads in terms of closeness.<br /><br />You'd be better off trying to sharpen an old RQ12 head instead of going with this one.
  961. Exact Replacement for my razor
  962. The head works fine but I made the mistake of taking out a blade to clean under it. It's never gone back in and stayed in. It falls out every single time I use the razor. I'm afraid to clean under the other two blades. Complete waste of money.
  963. After reading so many negative comments I was almost at the point of ditching the whole system and starting over. However I did buy the new replacement head and these are my comments. It's certainly a lighter accessory than the original, feels lighter and looks / sounds &#34;tinny&#34; by comparison. The empty / clean routine is different, seems awkward at first (and a bit odd to have to re-learn the system when I've had the original flip-open type for 2-3 years). So it looks, feels and sounds different, less heavy duty and cheaper. However.....it actually works quite well and does what it's meant to do! I don't see any loss of performance just because it's a lightweight design etc. It seems to work very well (only 1 week in). It's hard to say if it will last the test of time (the old heads were more than good for a year if looked after) so I'll have to wait and see, but I'm glad I didn't throw my Norelco shave system away.
  964. Works better than original but a little harder to clean

  978. I was very worried reading these other reviews, but could not justify paying the 300% premium on the old, discontinued heads. Glad I got this one - it renewed my old SensoTouch to what feels like a new generation shaver!<br /><br />You immediately notice that the shave heads are a lot more &#34;agile&#34;, with more angle and easier spring loads, following the contour of your face that much better.<br /><br />The now metal outer rings make it glide much better and cooler than the previous plastic, and also seem to improve the shave around the edges. I was amazed by how much smoother and closer the shave was with this new head. I couldn't cut myself no matter how hard I tried despite my incredibly sensitive skin. (I only use this razor for a wet shave with a cooling shave gel.)<br /><br />Metal equals resonance, which means this is slightly louder than the old head. It actually helps you because you can HEAR the beard stubble and intuitively know which areas need a second go-over.<br /><br />The modular design is a sturdier and more sustainable replacement than the old heads. You will not break them off by dropping your razor, and cleaning is so much quicker and easier. By switching out only the blades or foils when needed, you produce less waste and save money.<br /><br />The truth is in the shave, and this instantly convinced me, upgrading my aging SensoTouch 3D to something that properly feels like a new generation of shaver.
  979. I purchased the new RQ 12+ replacement head for my 8000 series shaver and it works really well, better than the original head and cleans much easier. This product is definitely a winner, and as a bonus, Norelco has indicated that they may offer just the rotary blade sets in the future! I think that is a great idea. This head is much easier to clean and dry than the original attached to the shaver. You don't even have to remove the head, just the blade section. Rinsing both the head attached to the shaver and the blade set separately allows both to be cleaned and dried more efficiently. Great job of engineering on this one, Norelco!
  980. no very dull do not cut very good

  994. Excellent. Works perfectly. Prompt delivery.
  995. Pretty decent replacement cartridge. It seems a lot sturdier than the old rq12, and the curved shape means I don't have to press down as hard when shaving my neck. It still has problems lifting hairs that grow flat against the skin, though I suspect using an electric preshave oil would help.
  996. This product is horrible. Do not buy it . The original RQ 12 blades are so superior and most unfortunate these are no longer available. Again do not buy these replacement blades. Its like running a tractor along your face. !
  997. I think these new heads are fine; they certainly are much better than the old, worn dull heads that I had been using. For the first couple of days they did seem to irritate my face a bit, but I think my skin was just adjusting to the new, sharper blades. Obviously, there are some people who have had a different experience, but I would recommend trying these before spending lots of money on the original style.
  998. Gives a nice close shave, but it is very difficult to put back together after cleaning. Once back together, it falls apart again easily.
  999. Perfect replacement fit.
  1000. I have to be honest. When I first saw all the bad reviews about this replacement head, I started looking for a different shaver. I'm from Ecuador and when I but at Amazon I have to wait about a month to get the products, and then, there is no way I can return the items.<br /><br />Nevertheless, I couldn't be happier with my purchase. I don't understand the bad reviews at all, this is the best shave I have ever gotten, is even better than the original blades. It may be a little different, but the construction and the performance is definitely better than the old RQ12. I feel I have a new shaver and want to shave twice a day because of the nice feeling I get with this replacement head.<br /><br />Seriously, I don't know if I'm crazy or Philips changed this head because of the bad reviews, but I can trully tell you that this is one of the best purchases I have ever made.
  1001. A solid improvement over the last head. Cuts extremely well on broad areas, though not as closely on the lip areas.   1002. replaced my 9250's RQ12 head with this.<br />smoother than RQ12, and makes less noise.<br />for RQ12+ you can replace knives individually not the entire head.
  1003. I hesitated to buy this given all the negative reviews, but I was pleasantly surprised as it performs better than the original at least for me. Faster shaving times, less passes required, at least as close a shave if not closer, better shaving below the nose, and I do not find it noisier, in fact my wife mentioned that she thinks it's quieter than the original. For comparative purposes my original head was 13 months old.<br /><br />On the down side it seems more complicated to clean with more steps and more disassembly required than the old head. A fair trade off for a faster shave in my opinion.<br /><br />Perhaps there have been different iterations of this new head, the earlier ones being poorer quality, hence the poor reviews. This one works well.
  1004. Because of all of the bad reviews I waited to see how the replacement head worked for me over the course of 4 months. First the blades do not shave as well as the original blades. Second they are better than the replacement blades that are listed for my shaver model. I researched and found these blades would also fit my razor model but using them makes the razor no longer fit in the original travel case which is not a deal breaker because of the better shave. Third comparing the original RQ12 blades to this replacement blade the original RQ12 blades were of a much higher build quality that had to cost more to make so it is certain that costs were cut to increase profits on these blades. Fourth I can understand why the people who purchased the high end shaver this replacement head is for are upset with the quality of the replacement head since the shave quality did decrease. Fifth I can live with it because of the quality of the shaver and that these blades do shave better than the original blades and replacements for my shaver model. The shaver model I have is 1060X and the replacement blades listed for it are RQ10 which were terrible compared to the blades that came with the shaver which did not make sense since they were supposed to be the same.
  1005. These are of a different design than the original I got with the razor. Needs getting used to and not sure if I really like them.
  1006. Because of the plethora of negative reviews I waited three weeks and over 20 shaves with the new blades before writing this review. In some ways I think the negativity is overblown ,in others ,totally justified. Whats OK: 1) the new system cleans easy and well, just different from the original system.In some ways it is a throwback to the way the older and cheaper XL's cleaned. It takes a little longer to remove the blades from the head, and yes you get your hand wet holding them under the hot water , and yes you need to let them dry before you return them to the head. But so what really. They clean well and just as quickly as the originals. 2) Yes they are a little noisier than the original system, but not to the point of being an intrusion to the music on the radio , and it is not an unusual or irritating noise. It sounds like , well, an electric shaver. 3) The shave at first was not as good as the original head/blades.However after a couple of weeks and paying some attention to what I was doing ,it got to be acceptable and in fact comparable to the shave with the original head/blades. But with a couple of caveats. It takes longer to get the same result and requires more pass overs with the razor. Whats Not So OK : 1) The shave is not nearly as comfortable and smooth . I never noticed a feeling of pulling or tearing whiskers with the original blade system, I do with this one .Just not the same smooth, comfortable shave. 2)Battery life is shortened because the shave takes longer .3) The new system looks bulky ,cumbersome sitting on the head of my senso touch 1250X . Whats Unacceptable : What I find unacceptable and utterly inexplicable is Philips/Norelcos' complete disregard for its customer base and their obvious dissatisfaction with the new blades and the way they have been foisted on the customers. What was done was essentially a major change to the design and operation of a very popular product. Seems to me that from a purely &#34;customer satisfaction &#34;point of view Norelco at a minimum should have left the option to continue to buy the original head/blade system for those that wanted to do so .They didn't and so the only way to get the original-system replacements is to pay astronomical prices to merchants , for what was already an expensive system. If Norelco had continued to make the original system available as an option of choice we would not see the price gouging that is going on .I think Philips/Norelco owed that to its customer base. I will continue to use the shaver,with the new blades.Hopefully the replacement blades will be reasonably priced when I need them because they will not come with a base, it will be just the shaving blades. But I will never feel the same loyalty and comfort I have in the past when purchasing a Philips or Norelco product, given the way they have treated their customers in this fiasco. And I will give much more attention to whatever competitive product is out there. Update 4/29/2015 ,after thinking more about my dissatisfaction with the new blades I asked myself why I was putting up with mediocrity in the shaving experience and the shaving result . Answer, because I have always used Norelco shavers . Not much of a reason to suffer mediocrity every morning 365 days a year is it ? I went on line ,did a lot of research on alternative electric shavers, wound up focusing on Braun , Series 5 & Series 7 . Got one of each to try and wound up keeping the Series 7 ,which I plan to review on the proper web page for that product. The point however is that I am now again satisfied with my shaving experience ,and the daily shaving result , Perhaps that is what we should all do, move on to another product,and perhaps Philips/Norelco will get the message going forward.

  1024. This new head is terrible compared to the old one. It pulls (painfully!) whereas the old one never did. It also doesn't flex outward the same way resulting in missed spots.
